title: R42741
content: The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents, with coverage options including individual, family, and self plus one plans. Participation is voluntary, with about 85% of employees and 90% of retirees enrolled. Plans are either fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs), with shared premiums between the government and individuals. All plans cover basic services like hospital and physician care, with varying cost sharing through deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance. The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents through fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs). Premiums are shared between the government and individuals, with all plans covering basic services like hospital and physician care. Prior to FEHB's creation in 1959, federal employees had to obtain health insurance on their own or through union plans. President Truman's Commission recommended federal government health insurance coverage in 1951, leading to the passage of the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established parameters for eligibility, coverage options, and premium cost-sharing between federal employees and the government. The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) oversees the program and has the authority to contract with insurers. The general model of FEHB, where enrollees choose from various private insurance plans, has remained consistent despite amendments to the act. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established the model of FEHB where enrollees choose from competing private insurers. While the general model has remained consistent, aspects such as premium cost-sharing and eligibility have been modified over time through legislative changes. Policymakers and researchers have shown interest in FEHB as a model for health insurance programs and for expanding coverage to certain individuals. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established the FEHB model where enrollees choose from competing private insurers. Policymakers and researchers have been interested in using FEHB as a model for expanding health insurance coverage to various individuals. The FEHB model is seen as successful in allowing enrollees to make cost-conscious choices and controlling overall program costs. There have been suggestions to export aspects of the FEHB model to other health care programs, expand access to FEHB, or create new programs based on FEHB for coverage of non-federal workers or retirees. Some policymakers have introduced legislation to create new programs or expand FEHB eligibility, while others have considered using FEHB features for state-level health insurance exchanges. Some policymakers have embraced the idea of expanding FEHB eligibility for individuals like small business employees or the uninsured. Lessons from FEHB may be useful for state and federal officials establishing health insurance exchanges under the ACA. Congressional interest in FEHB extends beyond its potential as a model for other programs, as Congress has a financial interest and legislative authority to maintain its function. This report aims to explain how FEHB has evolved and Congress's role in its viability and sustainability. Congress has a financial interest in the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program and has the authority to restructure it. The report details how Congress has interacted with FEHB, including conditioning federal funds on policy changes, adjusting the government's share of premiums, modifying eligibility, and impacting the relationship between Medicare and FEHB. Congress can place conditions on federal funds to make changes to FEHB, as seen in past legislation. The Appendix provides a summary of the enacting FEHB legislation and a list of laws that have amended FEHB. Congress can impose conditions on federal funds to make changes to FEHB, such as prohibiting the use of funds for abortions except in certain circumstances.
